summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Missouri today entered a final judgment in favor of Keller Farms, LLC, a Missouri-based agribusiness company, and its owner, Dennis McGarity, in a civil injunctive action.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Kansas City, Missouri on July 6, 2019, Keller Farms and McGarity agreed to settle a civil action brought by the Missouri Department of Agriculture (D.A.D. ) in which the court found that McGarity violated the antifraud provisions of Section 537.340 of the federal securities laws and ordered him to pay a civil penalty of $10,000.  The settlement is subject to court approval.  Keller Farms also agreed to pay disgorgement of $2,500 and prejudgment interest of $1,500.  In a related administrative proceeding, the court denied Keller Farms' motion for a new trial on the basis that it did not have sufficient evidence to determine whether McGarity was liable for crop damage.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC’s complaint, the defendants consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins them from violating the charged provisions and orders them to pay civil penalties of $15,000 and $1 million, respectively, in the amount of $20,000, each of which is deemed satisfied by Keller Farms’ settlement with the D.A., the District of Columbia, and the Missouri Secretary of State’s Office of Inspector General.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-10221 (Aug. 2, 2019).  The SEC acknowledges the assistance of the Missouri Attorney General and the Federal Bureau of Investigation in this matter.  On June 5, 2020, the SEC filed an emergency action against McGarity and the Stewarts, charging him with violations of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and with aiding and abetting Keller Farms violations of Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4)-8 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and Rule 206(3)-8 thereunder.  Among other things, the complaint alleges that Keller Farms failed to adequately disclose to the jury that it had received a warning letter from the Department that it likely caused herbicide drift on its property, and failed to disclose to McGarity that he likely caused it to drift onto Keller Farms property.   The complaint also alleges that the defendants violated Section 17(a)(1) of The Securities Act of 1933, Section 13(b)(2) and Rule 13b2-1 thereunder and Section 15(a) of
